reviewText:
REVIEW ON GAME:

I first started playing WoI after about a month or so afters its release, before that, I had been an avid BoI player. I came back to WoI for a little while and noticed that a lot of the issues I had beforehand were fixed. These were mostly text issues, but there were also some dramatic game changes as well that veterans of the game will notice rather quickly.

TL;DR - The game can be rewarding if you enjoy games that baby-feed the everloving ♥♥♥♥ out of you. Game rating is at the bottom.

War of the Immortals is a fairly decent dungeon-crawler-esque themed game. There's your standard stuff: instances, PvP, and a story line that can be followed through the Scenario" type quests the game offers you. Where this game shines and fails in is the gear aspect and in the leveling portion. You're essentially hunting for gear
date: which is to be expected in any sort of RPG; the problem lies in the fact that you level too fast to let the gear sink in. There are just too many ways to level up quickly in this game. During the "tutorial" segment (the parts of the game that take place before the player recieves his/her first set of GG at level 45) you're essentially doing one quest per level up. And on top of that
recommended: the game doesn't offer that many difficult quests. Scenario quests are mostly gathering or killing certain enemies. The player is spoiled with rewards every 10 levels
hoursPlayed: with the exception of mid-game levels (80-90) where the player is rewarded every 5. At level 50
voteText: one of these rewards is an item called a "Rock of Trials" which is specific to an instance that is also unlocked at level 50
helpfulPercent: called the Paladin Trials. At the end of the instance
votesHelpful: a Rock of Trials can be used to open a rather large chest that gives the player a massive amount of EXP. I personally ran this instance the second I hit level 50 with my Slayer and used a Rock of Trials at the end. Needless to say
votesTotal: I instantly jumped up 6 levels. You're given 10 of those rocks
votesFunny: mind you. I believe a level 60 reward is an item called "Ominous Orb" which is practically an instant level-up; the player is given 10 as well. The game also incorporates 1.5x and 2.0x experience through their respective stones which warrant half an hour of the depicted type of experience bonus. Leveling only slows down after around level 90 or so. Where is this a problem
commentsCount: you might ask? Gear is layed out as such: Tutorial gear would be anything warranted before level 45
column16: where the player runs through Magnetos to seek the first set of GG. This gear includes Greens; yes
column17: this game has a gear colour system
column19: a fairly mediocre one. Golden Gear is mainly used by PvE enthusiasts
column20: and are earned through other instances such as Specter Island (lvl. 60) and Evernight City (lvl.75) for example. After level 45
column21: your next set is earned at level 60. THERE IS NO GEAR IN BETWEEN THESE LEVELS. Soul Gear is much more difficult to achieve
column23: much more valuable. It used to be mainly for PvP only
column24: but has seemed to have adapted into an all-around set of gear that can be used for any situation. After you recieve your set of  level 45 GG
column25: you level fairly steadily until level 50
column27: you're a level 70+ with still a few pieces of level 45 gear. Get in a guild
column29: and run instances together to trade for the pieces of gear you need to stay on track. It's almost impossible to obtain gear on your own
column30: the drop rates are low enough as it is.\n\nCharacter customization is fairly limited. Most of the classes aren't gender locked
column31: with the exception of the Enchantress. That being said; however
column32: there aren't very many facial options or hair styles (the hair colour is also locked to the style which is pretty annoying). Perfect World HAS the technology and resources available to further their character customization. Perfect World International was released in North America on 2
column34: 2008 and offered a larger variety of character customization features. Nothing too astonishing
column35: but there's a clear difference in character customization if you compare the two.\n\nThe other issue I have is with the buff given to players in the level 40-100 range. This buff is called We Believe In You and it is the
column37: the most annoying thing that could possibly be given to players. It upgrades at levels 46 and 61
column38: and lasts for 4 hours. If the extreme leveling wasn't enough
column39: you'll love this. The buff grants a bonus damage to all monster types by "X"
column40: and gives "Y" mana and 1 rage every 5 seconds. It's honestly the worst thing ever. As if the game didn't hold your hand enough. What's the point in doing the kill quests if I just kill everything in one hit? That's not fun
column41: nor is it challenging. If I could make any changes to this game
column42:
it'd be this:

- Harder bosses and enemies
- Stricter leveling (I've seen people that can hit level 120 in about 2-3 weeks)
- More character customization
- Better animations
- More gear in between levels
- Larger maps
column43: bigger hubs and larger amounts of hubs\n- More instances
column44: and make the existing ones more of a challenge. I DON'T want to be able to solo them without issue.\n- Replace the Awakened Lineage feature with a skill tree system. Your class should be your CLASS
column45: not CLASSES. The Lineage feature is just a choppy clone of dual-speccing.\n- Clean up the game
column46:
for Christ's sake. Just because a few of the text issues were fixed doesn't mean that all of the issues are.



REVIEW ON COMMUNITY:

If you can get in a guild or get friends together
column47: you should be fine. The forums are dead
column48: but there are still a couple of loyal fans that still log on. Chats are flooded with trade offers
column49:
and other than that no one seems to want to really do anything anymore.



RATINGS:

Game: 6.5/10 - If you enjoy a challenge
column50: this is not the game for you. If you're more of a casual player that just wants to enjoy a dungeon-crawler with some friends without much stress
column51: go on ahead and download it. I can see the appeal
column53: it could have been better.\n\nCommunity: 3/10 - The once promising player base is becoming barren
column54: and the forums haven't been active in months. This may be due to the probationary period that PW has enabled on their forums
column55: limiting newly registered players from creating threads. The guilds I have been in are fairly strict on dailies and often kick players for not participating on a dailty basis. I'm shocked that there's enough of a player base to even say that guilds still exist.\n\nOverall Opinion: War of the Immortals can be fun at times

column57: but the developers severely impacted their standings by making their leveling system

reviewText:
I'll preface by saying I am an avid MMO fan.  I love a challenge, and a good grind, and always like to see mechanics and gameplay features that branch beyond the genre.

I invested less than an hour into the game, but I'll give you my firsthand experience as objectively as possible.

The game looks flashy, but dated looking.  Character and monster design look like a lot of effort went into them, but the lighting effects are a bit overdone.  Map designs are very well done and have a heavy western RPG feel to them.  The game lacks antialiasing, so once you zoom into the characters, you see blocky edges that really shows how dated this game's design really is.  High level character design is over the top, in an almost costume jewelery looking fashion.  There must be a ton of gear in this game, as it seems like you get upgrade after upgrade rather quickly from doing quests.

The Music feels epic in it's tone, but as I listened to a few of the map themes, I got the feeling of dischord and off-the rails digital symphonics that just didn't sound right after a while.  The combat sounds were mid level, but I found myself wanting to shut the game off after 15 minutes as the over flashy combat lighting and redundant grunting attack sounds began to quickly assault the senses.

Combat feels clunky, poorly timed, and a bit underdone.  Compared to other games the archer's gathering animations were laughable, and the jumping shot attack seemed rather silly.  I'm sure there is more epic looking attack animations as the game goes on, but I'm sure the poorly timed attack motif is something that does not change.

Auto-pathing to each quest took my mind off the actual game world as I delved into the interface. tons of upgrades look to be available, and I mean tons.  I like that kind of thing but I couldn't get past the combat to really give this game a try.  Royal  Quest is still doing it for me since August 2014, however I thought I'd give a few other Steam MMO's a try.

If you want some easymode auto path autoattack gaming, you can appreciate this game for what it is, but I personally can't.

reviewText: It's much less action than many action mmorpg games nowadays, which is really good thing. War of the Immortals reminds me of really good mmorpg game 2moons/Dekaron. It even have done few things better like fight with bosses - I think those are more effective in this game. Still, that doesn't make game a better from 2moons/Dekaron or even worth playing. Even tho I don't need much from game from this genre, War of the Immortals still fail to entertain me. From beggining, you more run around from place to place, from NPC to NPC, than actually fighting and when you finally do it, all you get is exp, with almost no stuff drops. Not sure how it's later but at earlier game you level up rather fast - few monters combined with few quests will get you next level. Also, I'm not sure how active this game is - I was the only one at beggining areas (still saw some people in city) but main chat is focused only on <item name> offer". Not much fun if you ask me. Still

reviewText:
Let me say right up front: Yes. This is a P2P. But if you look at it, aren't MOST MMOs?

I am a casual gamer, which basically means I play the game with whatever gear I get by questing. For the most part, this strategy serves me well for this particular game. I've clocked 15 hours of gametime and I'm at level 60.. And I haven't spent a penny. Now the temptation is there, of course, but the items that are available only to paying players are mostly vanity items to essentially show off you're a paying gamer.

The gameplay is straightforward. There are no maps to memorize; you click your destination and you are automatically routed to it, walking (or riding your mount) through brilliantly designed landscapes.

At first glance this game reminded me of WarTune and League of Angels. The moment I stepped into the game I was proven wrong. It's better. Having been a lifelong fan of MMOs, I finally found one I can call home.

TL;DR: Kick-♥♥♥ game. Pay if you want to, but it's not required. You level fairly quickly if you're dedicated and other gamers are quick to help you if you get stuck. Definitely worth getting.

reviewText:
Generally I wont call this a really Awesome MMO. Firstly I have to say this is one of the most repeative but yet rewarding MMOs out there.

You have 9 base classes ranging from your typical ranger/warrior/mage/healer and sub-categories.
With locked races and non-locked male/female gender. What is unquie about this game is the
botting service in the game, which has auto-potting system and exp stones gathered from cash shop or rewards from your class quests. A Pet system with a % chance to capture a pet based on its level & stats and skills based on the charater statics such as melee/magic/range. Depending on the class you are playing. it is wise to have a Tanking pet or DPS pet & a unquie mount pet for your class.

Players are to do mainly, daily dungeons and quests everyday it resets and you get gold +exp and craftable items and rewards for leveling up. It has a simple & yet fun way of doing daily quests from guild stuffs harvesting crafting & dungeon crawling. It also has its usual generic quests apart from the dailys which isn't much. Most of these quests would last you about 3-4 hours on average after you get to lv70-80 onwards. Where story quests are mostly nonexistent at this point.

Its fun with the aspect of being simple & relaxing game. I must warn you it gets very repeative though those daily dungeoning & completing repeative tasks to level up it can get a little boring but its awesome when you know the max level of this game is only 120 and in 100 hrs you can easily get to lv 100. The main aim is to hit lv 120 for the PVP aspect of this MMO where the true fun lies in.


I do recommand you getting a guild, its very essential in this MMO the sooner the better. Unless you have at least a group of 4-5 friends.
This MMO has a quick end game mostly aimmed towards pvp. Too busy or just too lazy to to grind, this is just the MMO for you. A MMO, more rewarding to play with a group of friends or to burn some time off your miserable waking life. xD

Final Vedict: 6/10

Updated: 26th Nov 2013

reviewText:
Garbage game.

1. Super low framerate even on an i7 gtx 970 system
2. No options to increase UI size or font size so if you are playing on a screen res higher than 800x600, everything is super tiny
3. MMORPG gameplay meets diablo. Point, click, sit back and watch. (with typical eastern mmo junk like leveling up 5 times in 2 minutes from the same spawns)
4. Perfect world pay 2 win

Trust me, dont waste your time downloading the game, and then downloading the 20+ patches. The game runs horrible, looks frelling awful, and is worse than mobile games of the same type.

reviewText:
Ever wanted an MMORPG that you could so totally veg out upon?
Well, now you can! Because War of the Immortals is bringing you the new meaning to the word 'fun'! Cause even if you have no skills in playing games whatsoever, you can let this game play for you! =D

This game is a chinese gold farmer bot's wet dream!

Care about graphics? Well ♥♥♥♥ no.
Things looks wonderful nice up close but holy ♥♥♥♥ does quality changes drawing out. Though, there are many innovative designs that typical of the asian style MMO.

Care about storyline?
It's ok.

Care about quests?
This game literally does it for you! Just click on the underlined quest and the game literally pathfinds you to the area or the person to meet!

Care about class variety?
Well, I ike it. There are 8 classes. Berzerker, Champion, Duelist, Enchantress, Heretic, Magus, Ranger, Slayer and Harbinger.

Care about lvling?
Well ♥♥♥♥ you lvl up every 2 quests = 5mins.

Don't forget to pick up your free pet Sunglasses Kangaroo! It kicks!

reviewText: I was expecting this to be awful going in and even then i was amazed at how bad it was. Running on a modified RTS engine, using stolen Torchlight & Titan Quest sound effects (and probably other assets but I'm not playing this longer), defaulting to a 1028x720 windowed mode, and a locked camera (zoom but no pitch) make this a serious contender for the worst F2P game on Steam. Don't bother playing this or any other PWI games.

reviewText:
I've had this game for about a week. I used to be an avid Battle of the Immortals player (BoI was a prequel to WoI) and I was unamused that the games are almost identical, but WoI has a few more features. It is still a decent game, but it is extremely pay to win, as all Perfect World games are. If you get to know the company, you will realize that they are only determined to receive money and have no care for their players.

Pros:
+Kinda addicting
+Interesting story
+Quests and dungeons alike
+Can be decently played without donating (why would you?), but can be hard later on
+Sick glowing gears
+Intricate pet system (2nd best - Rappelz has the best pet system known to date IMO.)
+Leveling rewards

Cons:
-Almost identical to its predecessors
-Very repetitive later on
-Can be boring later on
-Pay to win increases drastically after level 85-90
-THE WORST customer support. Period.
-Energy and purchasing are required to use world chat / server chat
-Nobody to play with at lower levels, thankfully it's easy to solo up to about 90
-Leveling Rewards

Overall:
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 4/10 (If it was 3D I'd be impressed.)
Story: 7.5/10
Addiction/Lasting Appeal: 4.5/10
Pay to win: 9.5/10
Intricacy: 7/10

Total: 7.21/10

Meh. I'd recommend it for those who want a laid back MMO. This game gives you all you need and then some for just leveling.

reviewText: Well, I was an amazing Mmorpg at it's time. Lots of levels, dungeons, mobs, items, weapons and classes to play a huge storyline, where you can do it several times without getting bored, and there is a huge amount of content. I used to play it with friends and made a few characters, because the first levels are easy to pass, after 80 gets complicated, and it starst to get repetitive, so every now and then, I reinstaled it to level up one or two lvs more. It isn't worth it to play it anymore, the community is dead, and if you don't have a party, you can't do dungeons, so if you don't have missions, you can't level up, and without them, you don't get xp or armor or weapons. There is only a percentage of players, but they are more than lv 100, and they do it with friends, that's why, I don't recommend this game, or at least for now, in cause of the community. 4/10
